Author: Ayste

Comment: It is a phenomenon. America falls into these cycles. If there is a recession or rise in unemployment, the party in power during it loses. The people almost instantly turned on Republicans in 2007, and then Obama won. People became angry that Obama wasn't fixing things fast enough, and then Republicans dominated statewide elections in 2010. It seems like this is why the pendulum swings every 8 years.    Many conservative leaning independents just vote with their gut, and they don't usually look into things beyond what they heard from their family or what Fox News tells them. Once they get a good trade job, buy a house, and get a new truck, they think everybody else can easily just do what they did, and don't give a shit about making healthcare, childcare, or college tuition more affordable.      If under a Republican president they start losing their jobs or healthcare, they turn on them. Once a Democrat gets in the Oval Office, they think Republicans will make things better faster and get pissed at the Democrats for not instantly fixing everything.
Author: x_xHaunter313

Comment: The internet has fundamentally changed the ability for people to be patient. The dopamine hit from instant satisfaction is too addictive. The economy is not something that can be fixed rapidly and is so incredibly complex. The people who demand it be fixed instantly have no idea how it works. Tariffs are the perfect example. Yes, targeted tariffs can be an effective tool to level out the playing field and help grow domestic industries. But it takes time to build capacity to start producing domestically and get domestic competition to lower prices of domestic made goods. Like factories and technology takes enormous amounts of capital and time to build. Like for chip fabrication. Tsmc is 20 years ahead of everyone else in the world and are literally the only company in the world who have the technology and knowledge to build the most advanced chips. You can't just spin up a chip fab lab and "learn" how they do it.
